coredata.dc:title: Critical anomaly in the proton chemical shift of methylfluoride
coredata.dc:creator: Trappeniers, N.J.
Van Emden, F.W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The first experimental results are presented of an investigation on the density and temperature dependence of the proton chemical shift in CH3F between 40°C and 60°C and at densities up to 485 amagat, corresponding to pressures of about 1000 bar. A striking result of this investigation is the discovery of an anomalous behaviour of the proton chemical shift in CH3F in the gas-liquid critical region.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 54, numi^ CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1978 CRITICAL ANOMALY IN THE PROTON CHEMICAL SHIFT OF METHYLFLUOR1DE N.J. TRAPPEN1ERS and F.W. VAN EMDEN Van der Waals-I-aboratonum. Umversitcit ian Amsterdam. Amsterdam, The Netherlands (241th publication of the van der Waals Fund) Received 28 November 1977 The first experimental results are presented of an investigation on the density ;ind temperature dependence of the proton chemical shift in CH3F between 40°C and 60°C and at densities up to 485 amaaat, corresponding to pressures of about 1000 bar. A striking result of this investigation is the discovery of an anomalous behaviour of the proton chemical shift in CH3F in the gas—liquid critical region. 1. Introduction The study of high resolution NMR spectra in gases can be very useful for obtaining information about the influence of the intermolecular interaction on the cliemical shift and hence on the magnetic shielding constant and also on the correlation of molecular mo- tion. Up to the present, a considerable number of in- vestigations [1] has been carried out in order to study the influence of temperature and pressure on these spectra. In practically all these studies the pressure was limited to a maximum of about 200 bar because of the use of sealed glass tubes. Recently, however, Oldenziel and Trappeniers [2] have studied the proton chemical shift in methane up to 570 amagat and in ethylene up to 470 amagat, corresponding to pres- sures up to 2500 bar. Another point of interest is that, with a single exception [3], all these experiments were carried out outside the gas—liquid critical region. In 1968 Carr and co-workers [3,4] discovered a re- markable anomalous behaviour of the xenon magnetic shielding in the vicinity of the critical point. A possi- ble explanation for this anomaly was given in terms of critical density fluctuations [3]. The question arises whether this anomalous behaviour is particular to xenon or whether it is a general property of the mag- netic shielding in the critical region. Moreover, it might be interesting also to investigate the influence of elec- trostatic interactions on the nature of this shielding anomaly. This article reports the first results of a study of the temperature and density dependence of the chemical shift of the polar molecule CH^F. The puipose of the investigation was twofold: first, to investigate the chemical shift in CH3F over a large density range from 0 to 485 amagat, corresponding to pressures up to 1000 bar and, secondly, to focus the attention on the behaviour of the chemical shift in tlie gas—liquid critical region- The critical temperature of CH3F is 44.49°C, the critical density is equal to: p^ = 202.6, PA denoting the amagat density. 2- Experimental Tlie measurements were made with a Varian HR-60-V2100B spectrometer, equipped with a berylli- um copper high pressure vessel which was used previ- ously in high resolution high pressure research at the Van de Waals-Laboratory [2,5]. Inside the high pres- sure vessel the sample tube can he rotated at a rate of about 50 rev/s; the pressure inside the vessel can be vaned continuously between 0 and 2500 bar. The spectrometer lias been equipped with a double frequency modulated transmitter which can operate at 56.5 Mil/, (fluorine resonance) and 60 MHz (proton resonance). The required temperature control was ob- tained by means of a heated air flow type thermostat, built around the pressure vessel, which controls the temperature to within 0.01°C in the temperature range between 20°C and 70°C. Line distances were measured with respect to an ex- ternal reference consisting of a sealed glass capillary tube and containing a mixture of 50% by volume CgHg and 50% by volume CsH5CF3.This capillary 203 Volume 54, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1978 tube was placed in the centre of the sample tube and could withstand pressures up to 2500 bar. Line dis- tances could be reproduced 10 within 0.2 Hz. 3. Experimental results for the proton chemical shift inCH3F The proton chemical shift in Cr^F has-been inves- tigated by measuring the line distance 61 between the external reference line and the upfield line of the pro- ton doublet. In fig. 1 the variation AS1)1 in the line dis- tance 5" with respect to an arbitrary reference point, namely the line distance at zero density and 60.15°C, lias been plotted against the amagat density p/^. The value of 5" for tins reference point is 372.2 Il7, so that for the four temperatures of fig. 1. AS" =51]1 -272.2 Hz. H Froni fig. 1 it can be seen tliat, in general, 5? de- creases continuously with increasing density. Ilow- 1'ig. 1. The proton chemical shift in CH3l' as a ("unction of density and temperature. I i?. 2.T!^>.•bri^lJviou^of(A6H);l= AS? - (AS")11 at 48.28°C, 46.3()°C, 45.74"r and 45.40"C- cver, at 48.28°C and, more strongly so, at 46.30°C, 45.74°C and 45.40°C, it is clearly seen that in the vi- cinity of the Clitical density a hump-shaped anomaly appears on ths normal background behaviour. There- fore, in a purely formal way, the behaviour of the vari- ation A5" of the proton line distance S" as a function of temperature and density may be written as AS"^^")1^^")3, (1) where (A5") represents the background, while (AS'i1)" accounts for the anomalous behaviour. The background curve has been constructed by interpolat- ing grapliically between the low density and high den- sity data points. The anomaly (AS^)3, as obtained by subtracting (AS")1' from AS", is illustrated in tig. 2. It is clearly seen that the anomaly increases when the temperature approaches the critical temperature t^ = 44.49°C. The critical constants ofCr^Fhave been obtained from a separate investigation [6] set up in order to determine the necessary p VT data ofCH^F. The anomaly corresponds to a shift to a decreasing lo- cal magnetic field at the position of the hydrogen nu- clei in CH3F, i.e. an increase in magnetic shielding. It also appears to be nearly symmetrical with respect to the critical density. Another way of looking at the anomaly is to take in fig-1 a constant density, for ex- ample the critical density (P\)^ = 202.6, and to con- sider the shift as a function of temperature. For the critical isochore this leads to fig. 3, in which the critical anomaly is plotted as a function of 7"—7p. The extra- 204 1 March 1976 Volume 54, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I-'ig. 3. Tile anomaly in the proton chemical ihift, (AS^)3, as a function of temperature Jt the critic.il density and dt d re- sonJnce frequency of 60 MHz. polation to the critical temperature Ty i.e. T—T^ = 0, gives for the anomaly a maximum value. (Ao")^^ = 11 Hz. In order to obtain more information about this pro- ton shift anomaly as well as about the behaviour of the fluorine chemical shift in €'113? in the critical re- gion, the measurements of the proton and fluorine chemical shift will be further extended and the results will be presented in a next article. 4. Discussion From the experimentally found variation in '.;ie proton chemical shift, ASp, the variation in the pro- ton shielding constant Ao^ can be obtained by apply- ing a correction for the bulk susceptibility of the sam- ple, according to AaH=A5"+|7r.x^p. (2) Provided XcHaF ls a linear function of the density, which is a reasonable assumption, the susceptibility term will not affect the critical anomaly so that (A6")3 = ACT^. (3) in which Ao^ denotes the anomalous part of the pro- ton magnetic shielding. Up to the present the theory of the coefficient of the magnetic shielding, o, has been developed mainly for the low density gas region [1 ]. The most conve- nient treatment was the binary collision model of Raynes, Buckingham and Bernstein [7] (hereafter referred to as RBB), who have used a virial-type ex- pression of the form o(p) = Oo + Oi? + Gap2 +.... (4) According to RBB, the "second virial screening con- stant" o, can be written as o,=-^/AOp^cxp(-(//fcr) y.R2dRsm6ld0^s,m0^d0^d<p, (5) where U is the intci molecular pair potential and exp(- U/kT) a simple approximation for the radial distribution function. In expression (5) tlie pair inter- action Ao -,. can be divided into a number ot contri- butions: A0p.,,r = ;:AOp^)w + (A0pa,-,)i. + (ACpa,-,)..,, (6) where (AOpay-^y is the contribution due to the van der Waals-type interactions, (A0pgy.)p results from per- manent and electric moments and (Ao-gj,.)^ arises from magnetic anisotropy. Theoretical expressions for (^pJi^W. (^p.iir)? and (^pai^a are available in the literature: a review of these has been given by Homer [1]. Substitution of the principal model expressions in (5) together with a value for if, either a (6—12) Lennard- Joncs or a Stockmaycr potential, leads to numerical values for o;, which have been listed in table 1 togeth- er with the present experimental values for CT( . It can Table 1 Comparison of thcoreticdl and cxperimcntJl values of 01 in CH3l' r=40.35°C /=50.32°C r=60I5°C oi(ppm cm /mol) expcrimcntiil -27 ±4 - 20 ±3 -23 ±4 (oi)wRBB[7I Rummuns [8] -35 -17.4 -33.7 -17.0 -33 -166 (OI)F RBB [7] -23.7 -22.3 -20.6 (oi).., Schug[91 -1 -1 -1 205 Volume 54, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1978 be seen that the general feature of the different mod- els is a decreasing shielding with increasing density, in qualitative agreement with the results of fig. 1. How- ever, there is clearly no quantitative agreement. The critical anomaly in the proton shift cannot be explained by this type of shielding theories, because they all predict a linear relationship between shielding and density. Moreover, the theories are only valid in the low density gas region as at higher densities several assumptions made in the derivation of (5) become questionable. For example: the additivity of pair inter- action, the use of a two-centre potential function for non-spherical molecules at close distances and the ap- proximation, e\p(—U/kT), for the pair distribution function. It is interesting to note that the C^F shielding anomaly differs from the xenon anonidly [3,4] in the sense that the xenon anomaly amounts to an excess decrease in the shielding, while the €113 F anomaly rep- resents an increase in the shielding superimposed on the background behaviour. The form of the curve in fig. 3 suggests the possibility of describing the shift anomaly by means of a critical exponent. By plotting ln[(Ao-^)n,ax - ^ftl ^-""st \n(T-T^), a straight line with slope 0 = 0.48 ±0.07 is obtained. This is about half the value of the compressibility critical exponent 7= 1.08 ±0.06, as found from the pVT measurements [6]. It is therefore to be expected that the correlation of molecular positions and orientations in the critical region will play an important role in the molecular in- terpretation of the anomaly. This will be investigated in the following article [10]. head.ce:title: Critical anomaly in the proton chemical shift of methylfluoride

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Van der Waals-Laboratorium, Universiteit van Amsterdam, Amsterdam, The Netherlands (241th publication of the van der Waals Fund)

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The first experimental results are presented of an investigation on the density and temperature dependence of the proton chemical shift in CH3F between 40°C and 60°C and at densities up to 485 amagat, corresponding to pressures of about 1000 bar. A striking result of this investigation is the discovery of an anomalous behaviour of the proton chemical shift in CH3F in the gas-liquid critical region.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: N.J. Trappeniers and F.W. van Emden, Physica, to be published.
